questionnaire.sectionDescription: Map out who makes the buying decision, their roles, influence levels, and the approval workflow

questions.question: Who is the Economic Buyer? (signs the contract, owns budget)
questions.helpText: Who has the authority to approve the purchase and allocate budget?

questions.question: Who is the Champion? (internal advocate, drives process)
questions.helpText: Who internally champions the solution and drives the buying process?

questions.question: Other stakeholders involved in decision
questions.helpText: Who else needs to be involved or give approval?

questions.question: Is this a committee decision?
questions.helpText: Does this require consensus from multiple people or is it one person's call?

questions.question: How many approval levels?
questions.helpText: How many levels of approval are typically needed?

questions.question: Who does technical/security evaluation?
questions.helpText: Who evaluates technical fit, security, integration?

questions.question: How much do end users influence the decision?
questions.helpText: How much weight do actual users (SDRs, AEs) have in the decision?

questions.question: Decision-making style
questions.helpText: How are decisions typically made in this organization?

questions.question: Is procurement/legal involved?
questions.helpText: Does this go through formal procurement or legal review?

questions.question: Key decision criteria (in priority order)
questions.helpText: What factors matter most in the decision? List in priority order.
questions.placeholder: e.g., 1) ROI/cost savings, 2) Ease of use for team, 3) Integration with Salesforce, 4) Implementation time, 5) Vendor reputation...

economicBuyer.authority: string (what they control - budget, final decision)
economicBuyer.motivations: string (what drives them - ROI, risk mitigation, growth)
economicBuyer.concerns: string (what worries them - cost, risk, implementation)
economicBuyer.engagementStrategy: string (how to engage - business case, executive meetings)

champion.relationship: string (relationship to economic buyer - reports to, peer, same person)
champion.motivations: string (what drives champion - career advancement, solving pain)
champion.support: string (how to support champion - arm with content, references)

decisionComplexity.complexity: string (low/moderate/high/very high based on committee + approvals)

procurementProcess.whenInvolved: string (at what stage do they get involved)
requirements: array of what procurement needs - MSA, security review, etc.

dealBreakers: array of things that would kill deal

keyRelationships: array of roles to multi-thread to
multiThreading.priority: string (who to engage first, second, third)

contentNeeds: array of what champion needs - ROI calc, slides, etc.
championEnablement.internalSelling: string (how to help champion sell internally)

consensusBuilding.strategy: string (how to build consensus across stakeholders)

topics: array of topics to discuss with executive

riskFactors.singleThreadedRisk: string (risk if only talking to champion)
mitigationStrategies: array of how to mitigate these risks

economicBuyer.authority: Controls sales budget ($50K-$100K discretionary), can approve tools without CFO sign-off up to $50K annually. Final decision maker for sales stack.
economicBuyer.motivations: Hitting revenue targets, scaling team efficiently, proving ROI to CEO/board, career advancement (wants promotion to CRO). Motivated by tools that make team more productive and help hit quota.
economicBuyer.concerns: Worried about wasting budget on tools that don't get adopted. Concerned about implementation time (can't afford 3-month rollout). Nervous about team pushback. Reputation at stake if tool fails.
economicBuyer.engagementStrategy: Lead with ROI and business case. Show how tool directly impacts quota attainment. Provide executive-level content (one-pagers, board-ready slides). Schedule executive briefings focused on strategic impact, not features. Connect to their personal goals (promotion path).

champion.relationship: Reports directly to VP Sales (Economic Buyer). Champion manages day-to-day sales operations, owns CRM admin, tool evaluation. Close working relationship with VP Sales.
champion.motivations: Reducing manual work for SDR team, improving data quality, modernizing sales stack, being seen as strategic (not just admin). Wants to bring innovation to team and get recognition. Career goal: Director of Sales Ops.
champion.influence: High influence - VP Sales trusts their technical judgment and relies on them for tool recommendations. Champion's endorsement is critical. If champion says 'this won't work', deal is dead.
champion.support: Arm champion with: ROI calculator, competitive comparison, implementation timeline, customer references from similar companies. Help them build internal business case. Provide demo environment they can show to VP Sales. Make them look like hero who found the solution.

technicalBuyers.concerns: Data security (where is data stored?), compliance (SOC2, GDPR), integration security (API access to Salesforce), vendor risk assessment, data privacy. Want to ensure no security vulnerabilities.
technicalBuyers.engagementNeeds: Security documentation (SOC2 report, penetration test results, data processing agreement), technical architecture overview, integration security details, customer references from similar security-conscious companies. Need to complete security questionnaire.

influencers.influence: High - VP Sales will ask SDRs for feedback during trial. If SDRs hate it, deal is at risk. User adoption is critical for ROI.
influencers.concerns: Ease of use (can't be complex), doesn't add work, helps them hit quota, doesn't feel like micromanagement. Want tools that make their job easier, not harder.
influencers.engagementStrategy: Include SDRs in trial. Get them excited early. Show quick wins (time saved, more meetings booked). Make champions out of 1-2 SDRs who can advocate to VP Sales. User training and support is critical.

influencers.influence: Medium - consulted on ROI but don't have veto power under $50K. Would be involved if deal exceeds VP Sales's authority.
influencers.concerns: ROI justification, cost vs alternatives, budget impact, payment terms, contract length. Want to ensure financial prudence.
influencers.engagementStrategy: Provide detailed ROI analysis. Show cost of inaction ($860K wasted annually). Compare to alternatives (more expensive or less effective). Offer flexible payment terms if needed.

influencers.influence: Medium - review contract but typically don't block deals unless major red flags. Can slow process with contract negotiations.
influencers.concerns: Contract terms, liability, data privacy, termination clauses, indemnification. Want to protect company legally.
influencers.engagementStrategy: Start with standard contract. Be flexible on reasonable edits. Provide data processing agreement proactively. Use existing customer MSAs as templates to speed review.

endUsers.influence: High (users heavily influence) - VP Sales will trial with SDRs and listen to their feedback

decisionComplexity.complexity: Moderate - small committee but requires consensus between Sales Ops Manager (champion), VP Sales (economic buyer), and input from IT Security (technical buyer). Not overly complex but requires alignment.
decisionComplexity.averageDecisionTime: 6-8 weeks from first contact to signature. Can compress to 3-4 weeks if urgent.
decisionComplexity.consensusRequirement: Collaborative (input sought, leader decides) - VP Sales makes final call but wants consensus from Sales Ops and IT before proceeding

stages.name: Champion Evaluation & Internal Buy-In
stages.activities: Sales Ops Manager evaluates tool, runs trial with 2-3 SDRs, builds internal business case, gathers feedback. Creates presentation for VP Sales.
stages.successCriteria: Champion is convinced tool works, has positive SDR feedback, has built ROI business case. Ready to present to VP Sales.

stages.name: Executive Approval & Technical Review
stages.activities: VP Sales reviews business case, attends demo, sees trial results. IT/Security does security review in parallel. Customer reference calls. ROI validation with Finance (informal).
stages.successCriteria: VP Sales approves budget allocation. IT/Security completes security review with no major blockers. ROI is clear and justified.

stages.name: Contract & Procurement
stages.activities: Legal reviews contract, negotiates terms. Finance approves if needed. Signatures collected. Implementation planning begins.
stages.successCriteria: Contract signed, PO issued, kickoff scheduled. Implementation plan approved.

approvalWorkflow.totalDuration: 7-8 weeks typical, 3-4 weeks if fast-tracked with urgency
bottlenecks: IT Security review can take 2-3 weeks if backlogged
Champion building internal case can take 2-3 weeks if not guided
VP Sales schedule (hard to get on calendar)

procurementProcess.whenInvolved: Stage 3 (after executive approval, during contracting). Procurement only involved if deal exceeds $50K annually or if Legal flags it.
procurementProcess.typicalDuration: Adds 1-2 weeks for contract review and vendor approval process
procurementProcess.negotiationStyle: Collaborative but process-driven. They want to follow procedure but aren't aggressive negotiators. Will push back on non-standard terms but reasonable on most requests.

rankedCriteria.criterion: ROI / Cost savings - must show clear return
Ease of use for SDR team - can't be complex
Integration with Salesforce - must sync seamlessly
Implementation time - need fast rollout (<30 days)

mustHaves: Easy to use (SDRs can learn in <1 hour)

multiThreading.priority: 1st: Build champion relationship (Sales Ops). 2nd: Get SDRs excited during trial. 3rd: Engage IT Security early. 4th: Executive briefing with VP Sales (after champion advocacy).

championEnablement.internalSelling: Help champion position as strategic initiative ('modernizing sales stack', 'scaling efficiently') not just tool purchase. Frame as solving VP Sales's #1 problem (can't scale team). Make champion look like innovator who found solution.
championEnablement.politicalNavigation: Champion reports to economic buyer (clean reporting line). Main risk is IT Security blocking. Help champion engage IT early with proper documentation. Ensure SDRs are positive influencers.

consensusBuilding.strategy: Sequential consensus: Champion → Users → IT Security → VP Sales. Build support bottom-up so VP Sales sees unanimous support when they make decision.
consensusBuilding.alignmentMeetings: Week 2: Champion + SDR trial review. Week 3: Champion + IT Security review. Week 4: Champion presents to VP Sales with SDR testimonials. Week 5: VP Sales + IT + Champion alignment meeting.
consensusBuilding.objectionHandling: If IT Security objects: Address security concerns with documentation, customer references, compliance proof. If SDRs object: More training, better onboarding, show quick wins. If VP Sales hesitates: Reinforce ROI, create urgency, peer proof.

executiveEngagement.when: Week 4-5, after champion is convinced and trial is successful. Don't engage too early (before champion advocacy) or too late (after champion loses momentum).
executiveEngagement.how: Executive briefing (30 min), focused on business impact not features. Show ROI, reference customers, trial results. Let champion present (they've done the work). Vendor provides executive perspective and answers strategic questions.

riskFactors.singleThreadedRisk: High risk - if only talking to Sales Ops Manager and they leave or lose influence, deal dies. Must multi-thread to VP Sales, IT Security, and SDRs to reduce dependency on single champion.
riskFactors.championDepartureRisk: Very high risk - Sales Ops Manager job hopping is common in tech. If champion leaves mid-deal, typically adds 4-6 weeks to reset with new champion. Mitigation: Build relationships with VP Sales and SDRs so deal survives champion change.
riskFactors.consensusFailureRisk: Moderate risk - if SDRs hate tool or IT Security blocks, VP Sales won't override. Need unanimous support for deal to close. Mitigation: Include all stakeholders early, address concerns proactively.
riskFactors.procurementRisk: Low risk - procurement usually rubber-stamps under $50K. Adds 1-2 weeks but rarely blocks. Mitigation: Use standard contract, be flexible on reasonable terms.
mitigationStrategies: Multi-thread early (don't rely on single champion)
Build champion relationship with VP Sales directly (not just through Sales Ops)
Get IT Security involved in week 2-3 (don't wait until end)
Make SDRs champions during trial (get 2-3 evangelists)
Document all stakeholder concerns and address proactively
Provide champion with all enablement materials

rawAnswers.decisionCriteria: 1) ROI/cost savings - must show clear return on investment. 2) Ease of use for SDR team - cant be complex or require heavy training. 3) Integration with Salesforce - must sync seamlessly. 4) Implementation time - need fast rollout, under 30 days. 5) Vendor reputation - prefer established players with good support.
